annotation.TEXT: Ignoring the fact that the Volt Buckler is easily one of the most glitched weapons in any fan-game, defeating this version of Doc-Robot will make it so that energy pick-up's will give you twice as much ammo as they would normally. It's not overly helpful, but it's nice to have at least.
Nice coding on the oil trap, bro.
Despite being a secret boss, Wave Man isn't any more difficult than the rest of the Robot Masters. The fact that the Volt Buckler glitch works on him just makes it even sadder.

Like here, for example (again, I have no idea why this happens). In either case, beating this version of Doc-Robot gets you an actual Energy Balancer (which further questions as to why the Arrow Shot type power-up couldn't be represented by anything else).

With the optional bosses out of the way, we can focus on getting the last letter in Dyna Man's stage...which - when the alternate path is activated - is now mostly underwater (which makes even less sense given the background in some sections).

Wave Torrent is one of the few weapons in this game that has somewhat decent damage output. Despite this, it's not that much more useful than the Razor Blade. The water droplets that burst out when it hits a surface also don't contribute much either (since the main projectile phases out when it hits an actual enemy).

On hindsight in what was referred to the Volt Buckler's seemingly magic ability to glitch out and one-shot certain bosses (or just deal insanely varied damage), I found out that this isn't just limited to Bit Man. I have no idea what the cause for this is, but it turns out it effects a variety of other enemies (most of them, anyways).

I'm somewhat hesitant to call Wave Man's stage a "secret" one however (or even a separate stage of its own), since it's really just another alternate path in part of Oil Man's stage - along with addition of Nitro Man's theme (for some reason).

Before I move on to the final stages, there's still a few secrets that can be obtained in the main Robot Master levels. I figured it'd be best to clear out the remaining optional bosses (even though it's not necessary to complete the game, the rewards you get for doing this can help out a bit. That, and I'm pretty sure since I'm the only one who will ever bother playing this, I may as well show off the entirety of this game's flaws).
Once you get all of them however, you gain access to the last of the DOS Robot Masters that was seemingly left out of this game at first glance: Wave Man.
On further hindsight, the miniature Shield Attackers can be destroyed with the Volt Buckler. I'm pretty sure this is unintentional, but either way, it makes this section much easier.

I'm going to state this right now: The opening jump to this section is easily one of the most aggravating things I've come across in these fan-games. I honestly didn't think it was possible to make the first jump across these blocks due to how low the crushers go when they show up (that is, until I somehow managed to pull it off here). For the longest while, the only way I thought this section was possible was by way of a random bug that could occur when entering the room, causing the block pattern to trigger early.

For somehow getting through this obnoxious fight, you're rewarded with an increased ammo count for all of your weapons - doubling the reserves of each (Volt Buckler now has 8 shots instead of 4, for example). While this makes some of the more obviously better weapons easier to abuse, it doesn't do much for the other, more lack-luster entries (such as Dynamo Wrecker).

This version of Doc-Robot is easily the most annoying of the bunch (mainly since he takes after Oil Man's ability of jumping up to places where you can't shoot him). It also further serves as a testament to the poor coding of the game, as Doc-Robot can usually only be hurt once he lands down to briefly fire Torch Man's ability at you. Sometimes he lingers on this for a while, sometimes he jumps right back up immediately after using it, and other times he doesn't fire it at all. I'm more than willing to bet no one even bothered to check the AI of this boss (let alone beta-test this whole game).

Although I should have mentioned this before, now seems as good of a time as any to do so: Once you get one of these letters, you better make sure you complete the rest of the stage without dying. The game actually doesn't save or count the letter unless you beat the stage on the same life you collected it. This means that if you pick up a letter but die to a Robot Master, you get to go through the stage all over again just for another shot at obtaining the letter.
